head.title: Synthesis of V-doped In2O3 Nanocrystals via Digestive-Ripening Process and Their Electrocatalytic Properties in CO2 Reduction Reaction | ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces

meta.content: Synthesis of V-doped In2O3 Nanocrystals via Digestive-Ripening Process and Their Electrocatalytic Properties in CO2 Reduction Reaction

The development of synthetic methods for monodisperse nanomaterial is of great importance in science and technology related to nanomaterials. The strong demands to prepare exceptionally monodisperse nanocrystals have made digestive-ripening one of the most sought-after size-focusing processes. Although digestive-ripening processes have been demonstrated to produce various metals and semiconductors, their applicability to oxides has rarely been studied despite various unique properties and applications of oxide nanomaterials. In this work, we demonstrate the successful synthesis of monodisperse V-doped In2O3 nanocrystals via a modified digestive-ripening process. The nanocrystals have truncated octahedral shape faceted with eight (222) and six (220) planes. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report on the digestive-ripening synthesis of highly symmetrical doped oxide nanocrystals. Moreover, V-doped In2O3 nanocrystals exhibit electrocatalytic activities for CO2 electrochemical reduction and produce CH3OH, which has not been attainable from previously reported electrocatalysts based on indium or indium oxide. This distinctive catalytic property of V-doped In2O3 is attributed to the presence of V-dopants in the In2O3 host. Our demonstration has important implications for both nanocrystal synthesis and electrocatalyst development.

div.p:
The development of synthetic methods for monodisperse nanomaterial is of great importance in science and technology related to nanomaterials. The strong demands to prepare exceptionally monodisperse nanocrystals have made digestive-ripening one of the most sought-after size-focusing processes. Although digestive-ripening processes have been demonstrated to produce various metals and semiconductors, their applicability to oxides has rarely been studied despite various unique properties and applications of oxide nanomaterials. In this work, we demonstrate the successful synthesis of monodisperse V-doped In
2
O
3
nanocrystals via a modified digestive-ripening process. The nanocrystals have truncated octahedral shape faceted with eight (222) and six (220) planes. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report on the digestive-ripening synthesis of highly symmetrical doped oxide nanocrystals. Moreover, V-doped In
2
O
3
nanocrystals exhibit electrocatalytic activities for CO
2
electrochemical reduction and produce CH
3
OH, which has not been attainable from previously reported electrocatalysts based on indium or indium oxide. This distinctive catalytic property of V-doped In
2
O
3
is attributed to the presence of V-dopants in the In
2
O
3
host. Our demonstration has important implications for both nanocrystal synthesis and electrocatalyst development.

div.span: KEYWORDS:
ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
One of the most important issues in nanocrystal synthesis is controlling the size, size distribution, and shape of nanocrystals because these characteristics are closely related to the properties of the materials.
(1−4)
The strong demands for tuning the key characteristics of nanocrystals have recently led to a better understanding of the role of organic ligand molecules during the synthesis. At the early stages of the research on nanocrystal synthesis, the major role of ligands was considered to be simply passivating/capping the inorganic nanocrystals, providing stability against aggregation.
(5,6)
Later, it was recognized that ligands can interact with nanocrystals more actively and significantly affect the size and morphology of nanocrystals.
(7−10)
In this regard, a digestive-ripening process was discovered by Lin et al., whereby exceptionally monodisperse nanocrystals can be synthesized.
(11−15)
It involves refluxing an as-prepared nanocrystal suspension with an excess amount of ligands (also known as digestive-ripening agents), resulting in the simultaneous shrinkage of large particles and growth of small particles until an equilibrium size with a narrow distribution is reached.
(12,16)

Since then, digestive-ripening has become one of the most promising procedures for the preparation of monodisperse nanocrystals, particularly those of metals and semiconductors.
(4)
For example, various metals (e.g., Au, In, Ag, and Pd) and semiconductors (e.g., CdS, CdSe, CsPbBr
3
, and CuSnZnS
4
) are amenable to synthesis via the digestive-ripening process.
(11,16−21)
Furthermore, monodisperse metal alloy (e.g., Au–Sn, Au–Ag, and Ag–Cu), core–shell (e.g.,
[email protected]
and
[email protected]
), and, more recently, composite (Au/CdS) nanocrystals have been prepared through the process.
(22−27)
While most of them had spherical shapes, polyhedral metal nanocrystals such as icosahedral Ag and Au and semiconducting nanocrystals such as cubic and hexagonal CdS have also been synthesized.
(19,28,29)
However, in contrast to the metals and semiconductors, it has been difficult to synthesize well-defined oxide nanomaterials via the digestive-ripening process.
(30)
Synthesis of lanthanide oxide in the form of nanodisks was recently demonstrated, but other reports are scarce.
(31)

It is highly desirable to understand and develop synthesis methods for monodisperse oxide nanocrystals because they have a broad range of applications, such as gas sensors, solar cells, electronic devices, environmental remediation, and photocatalysts.
(32−35)
Synthesis methods involving the digestive-ripening process for oxide nanocrystals, particularly those with high symmetry, such as spherical and polyhedral ones, are yet to be investigated. Moreover, the synthesis of doped oxide nanocrystals via the digestive-ripening process has not been successfully demonstrated. Nonetheless, it is well known that doping oxide nanomaterials with metal ions often improves the properties of the host materials and/or endows them with novel properties.
(36)

In this study, we synthesized monodisperse V-doped indium oxide (In
2
O
3
) nanocrystals via a modified digestive-ripening process. The reduction in size and size distribution observed during the synthesis reaction confirmed that the nanocrystals were synthesized through the digestive-ripening process. It has been observed that the concentration ratio of the precursors is critical for digestive-ripening to occur properly. Moreover, the V-doped In
2
O
3
nanocrystals exhibited unique electrocatalytic activity toward the CO
2
reduction reaction (CO
2
RR). The V-doped In
2
O
3
generated CH
3
OH, which has not been observed from previously reported CO
2
RRs with In-based electrocatalysts.
(37,38)
This indicates that the doping had a significant influence on the reaction pathway of the CO
2
RR. We attribute the CH
3
OH production to the enhanced binding between the V-doped In
2
O
3
nanocrystals and *CO intermediates, possibly via π-backdonation.
(39,40)
Our results pave the way for the digestive-ripening synthesis of various oxide nanocrystals, particularly for the high selectivity of CO
2
reduction products.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.h3:
2.1. Materials for V-Doped In
2
O
3
Nanocrystals Synthesis
div.div:
Indium acetylacetonate (In(acac)
3
, ≥99.99%), vanadium(III) acetylacetonate (V(acac)
3
, 97%), oleylamine (OLA) (70%), oleic acid (OA) (90%), toluene (99.8%), and trioctylphosphine oxide (TOPO) (90%) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. Absolute ethanol (99.9%) was purchased from J. T. Baker. All of the chemicals were used as received.

div.h3:
2.2. Synthesis of V-Doped In
2
O
3
Nanocrystals
div.div:
First, 0.2 mmol of In(acac)
3
and 0.2 mmol of V(acac)
3
were added to 15 mL of OLA in a 100 mL three-neck flask. The mixture was heated to 280 °C in an N
2
atmosphere. When the solution temperature reached 280 °C, 5 mL of OA was injected into the reaction flask, and the solution was held at that temperature for 2 h. After the reaction was complete, the reaction solution was naturally cooled to room temperature without removing the heating mantle. The reaction products were precipitated by adding excess ethanol to the solution, followed by centrifugation at 10 000 rpm for 10 min. After the supernatant was discarded, the precipitate was dispersed in toluene. This washing procedure was repeated three times to eliminate impurities and unreacted materials. The precipitate was finally redispersed in toluene or used in a powder form for further characterization. To obtain TOPO-treated nanocrystals, we followed a previously reported process, as briefly described below. After the aforementioned washing step, the precipitate was added to the melted TOPO, followed by heating at 150 °C for 1 h and then precipitation with ethanol. To ensure the completion of the ligand exchange, the exchange process was repeated three times.

The size, morphology, and crystallinity of the nanoparticles were characterized via field-emission transmission electron microscopy (TEM, Tecnai, G2 F30) at the Korea Basic Science Institute. The particle-size distribution was determined from the TEM images using ImageJ software. The crystal structures were analyzed via TEM, selected-area electron diffraction (SAED), and X-ray diffractometry (Rigaku D, max-2500 V/PC) with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54 Å). The composition of nanoparticles was characterized via X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, VersaProbe, PHI 5000) with Al Kα radiation (
E
= 1.487 keV), Raman spectroscopy using a 532 nm wavelength laser (Renishaw inVia Raman microscope), and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy. The ultraviolet–visible (UV–vis) absorption spectrum was obtained using a UV–vis spectrophotometer (Varian, Cary 50). Inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS, Agilent Technologies, 7700x ICP-MS) was carried out for elemental analysis of solutions.

The V-doped In
2
O
3
nanocrystal catalysts (10 mg) were dispersed in a solution mixture of toluene (2 mL) and 5 wt % Nafion solution (20 μL), followed by 15 min bath sonication. The catalyst solution (50 μL) was spin-coated onto a freshly polished glassy C electrode at a rotating rate of 1000 rpm. This coating process was repeated six times. The catalyst-loaded glassy C was attached to a piece of Au/Al foil. An area of 1 × 1 cm
2
was exposed, the remainder of the electrode was masked with an insulating epoxy. Prior to use, all glassy C electrodes were mechanically polished with diamond paste (average diameter = 1 μm) and alumina paste (average diameter = 0.05 μm) using a polishing cloth. Then, they were rinsed with deionized water and sonicated in deionized water for 30 min.

Electrochemical CO
2
reduction tests were performed using a homemade three-electrode cell. The electrochemical reactor had two chambers that were separated by an anion-exchange membrane (Selemion AMV-N). A saturated Ag/AgCl electrode and a Pt plate were used as the reference and counter electrodes, respectively. All of the potential values were converted to the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) scale using the equation
E
RHE
=
E
Ag/AgCl
+ 0.197 V + 0.0591 pH. Both the anolyte and catholyte were 0.1 M KHCO
3
, and they were prepared by dissolving KHCO
3
(≥99.95%, Sigma–Aldrich) in deionized water (pH = 6.8). Before every measurement, the electrolyte was saturated with high-purity CO
2
gas (99.999%) for at least 2 h. Each compartment of the cell was filled with 12 mL of CO
2
-saturated electrolyte and purged with CO
2
for 30 min prior to the experiment. During electrolysis, CO
2
was allowed to flow into the cell at a constant rate of 20 sccm after passing through a water bubbler. The inlet flow was controlled by a mass flow controller, and the outlet flow was measured by a portable mass flow meter to confirm that there was no leakage.

For an analysis of the gas products, the outlet of the electrochemical cell was connected to a gas chromatography instrument (SRI Instruments Multiple Gas Analyzer #5) equipped with a thermal-conductivity detector and a flame ionization detector. Ultrahigh-purity Ar gas (99.9999%) was used as a carrier gas. The concentrations of the gas products were determined via the calibration curves, which were obtained using gases with known concentrations. For an analysis of the liquid products, liquid samples were taken after or during electrolysis and analyzed via
1
H nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy (Bruker, Avance III HD 500 MHz and/or Agilent Technologies, DD2 600 MHz). The liquid sample (700 μL) was mixed with 35 μL of 10 mM dimethyl sulfoxide in D
2
O and transferred to an NMR tube. The amounts of liquid products were estimated according to the calibration curves. The solvent presaturation technique was used for water suppression.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
This work reports a facile synthesis route for monodisperse V-doped In
2
O
3
nanocrystals. As illustrated in
Figure
1
a, this procedure is a one-pot process that can be conducted within a few hours. First, the solution containing precursors was heated to the reaction temperature. This led to the thermal decomposition of the precursors, followed by the formation of polydisperse noncrystalline nanoparticles (black solution). Second, the excess amount of digesting agent, i.e., OA, was injected. This hot-injection step induced the dissolution of the nanoparticles into molecular metal oleate cluster complexes, as indicated by the change of the solution color (from opaque black to transparent yellow) (
Figure
1
b).
(31,41)
This caused an abrupt increase in the concentration of metal oleate complexes and hence a nucleation burst and growth of nanocrystals (black solution). The size of the V-doped In
2
O
3
nanocrystals became uniform as the reaction proceeded. We notify that insufficient OA leads to incomplete dissolution of the nanoparticles as indicated by the opaqueness of the solution (
Figure S1
). The absorption spectra of the V-doped In
2
O
3
nanocrystals diluted in toluene indicated that they had an estimated band gap of 3.68 eV, which is consistent with previous reports (
Figure
2
a,b).
(42)

div.p: Figure 1. (a) Schematic of the experimental procedure and (b) photographs of the solution before and 0 min, 5 min, and 2 h after OA injection.

Figure 2. (a) UV–vis absorption spectrum and (b) Tauc plot of V-doped In
2
O
3
nanocrystals.

div.div:
TEM images of the samples collected at different reaction times clearly indicated that the nanocrystals were synthesized via a digestive-ripening process (
Figure
3
a–d). When the temperature increases to 280 °C, the thermal decomposition of the precursors In(acac)
3
and V(acac)
3
in OLA and consequently the formation of polydisperse noncrystalline nanoparticles occurred (
Figure
3
a). The TEM image indicated that these nanoparticles had a broad size distribution. Next, the injection of an excessive amount of the etching agent OA led to the etching of all the nanoparticles into molecular In-oleate and V-oleate cluster complexes, as indicated by the transparency of the solution (the second panel in
Figure
1
b). Then, the rapid increase in the concentration of the metal-oleates resulted in nucleation burst.
(8,31,43)
This caused the formation of V-doped In
2
O
3
nanocrystals with a broad size distribution and amorphous vanadium oxide (VO
x
) nanoparticles (
Figures
3
b and
S2
). Interestingly, the V-doped In
2
O
3
nanocrystals gradually became monodisperse, while the VO
x
nanoparticles eventually dissolve into the solution as the reaction proceeded (
Figure
3
b–d).
(16,44)
The dissolution of the VO
x
nanoparticles was confirmed with XPS and ICP-MS; V content in the solid product reduces as the reaction proceeds (
Figure S3
) and correspondingly increases in the liquid phase (In/V = 4.4:95.6 by ICP-MS). The TEM images show the narrowing of the V-doped In
2
O
3
nanocrystal size distribution. The corresponding histogram confirms this (
Figure
3
e,f); the average ± standard deviation of the diameter of the nanocrystals decreased from 11.5 ± 3.26 to 8.62 ± 0.89 nm over the reaction time from 30 min to 2 h after the injection. The decrease in the average size and the improved monodispersity of the nanocrystals strongly suggest that they grew via the digestive-ripening mechanism. The size of the nanocrystals obtained from the TEM images closely matched that estimated according to the Scherrer formula and X-ray diffraction (XRD) data (∼8.69 nm).

div.p: Figure 3. TEM images of the products obtained at different reaction times during the digestive-ripening process: (a) before OA injection and (b) 5 min, (c) 30 min, and (d) 2 h after the injection. Size histograms obtained (e) 30 min and (f) 2 h after the injection.

div.div:
The structural analyses indicated the high crystallinity of the final product, i.e., the V-doped In
2
O
3
nanocrystals. The XRD patterns showed how the crystallinity changed during the reaction (
Figure
4
a). Initially, the nanoparticles formed during the heating process prior to the OA injection lacked crystallinity, as evidenced by the absence of noticeable XRD peaks. The nanoparticles formed 5 min after the OA injection exhibited the crystallinity of cubic phase In
2
O
3
(JCPDS #06-0416). Finally, after 2 h of the reaction, highly crystalline V-doped In
2
O
3
nanocrystals were formed, as indicated by the high intensity of the cubic-phase peaks and the absence of secondary-phase peaks. The absence of vanadium oxide phases implies that most of the V ions were incorporated into the In
2
O
3
host lattice. The absence of a distinct peak shift upon doping is attributed to the similar ionic radii of V
3+
ions (0.78 Å) and In
3+
ions (0.80 Å).
(45,46)
Overall, the results indicate that the crystallinity increased during the reaction. The high-resolution TEM (HR-TEM) and SAED results confirmed the high crystallinity of the final product. The HR-TEM image shows the lattice fringes corresponding to the (220) and (222) planes of In
2
O
3
, where the
d
-spacing for the (220) and (222) planes was 3.59 and 3.05 Å, respectively (
Figure
4
b). Additionally, the diffraction pattern of the V-doped In
2
O
3
nanocrystals exhibited the characteristics of cubic In
2
O
3
(
Figure
4
c).
(47)

div.p:
Figure 4. (a) XRD patterns of V-doped In
2
O
3
nanocrystals obtained at different reaction times and cubic-phase In
2
O
3
(JCPDS #06-0416). (b) HR-TEM image and (c) SAED pattern of the product obtained after 2 h of reaction.

div.div:
The synthesis mechanism of the monodisperse V-doped In
2
O
3
nanocrystals was based on a modified digestive-ripening process (
Figure
5
). The nanoparticles were formed during the heating stage of the reaction. They exhibited irregularity in both composition and morphology and lacked crystallinity. XRD, TEM, and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) analyses indicated that they consisted of amorphous nanoparticles of various oxides, such as indium oxides, vanadium oxides, and indium vanadium oxides, with broad size distributions (
Figure S4
). These irregular amorphous nanoparticles were instantaneously etched into molecular complexes upon the injection of OA and, as a result, the solution became transparent. Consequently, the concentration of the cluster complexes rapidly increased above the threshold for nucleation, causing nucleation burst and nanocrystal growth. The V-doped In
2
O
3
nanocrystals nanoparticles observed at this early stage after the injection were crystalline to some extent and had a broad size distribution. This instant dissolution followed by renucleation distinguishes our process from the conventional digestive-ripening process. After this etching/nucleation stage, the nanocrystals undergo conventional digestive-ripening process, wherein the etching and growth competed.
(4)
This competition led to the balanced and uniform size of the nanocrystals.
(12,48)
Accordingly, the nanocrystal size distribution became narrow, and the average size decreased as the reaction proceeded. In contrast, in the traditional Ostwald ripening process, the average particle size increases during the reaction because the larger nanoparticles grow at the cost of thermodynamically unstable smaller nanocrystals.

div.p: Figure 5. Schematic of the suggested reaction mechanism.

div.div:
The TEM analysis indicated that the V-doped In
2
O
3
nanocrystals had a truncated octahedral shape (
Figure
6
a). The nanocrystals had 14 facets: eight hexagonal (222) planes and six square (220) planes, which are colored red and blue, respectively. The shapes of the nanocrystals in the TEM images correspond well to the projection of the truncated octahedron models, which are oriented accordingly. Moreover, low-magnification TEM revealed that most of the nanocrystals were faceted, as indicated by the yellow lines in
Figure
6
b. Most of the previous oxide nanoparticles synthesized via digestive-ripening method were not very well-defined or had a nanodisk shape; to the best of our knowledge, this is the first example of the synthesis of well-defined, highly symmetrical, monodisperse oxide nanocrystals.

div.p:
Figure 6. (a) HR-TEM images of truncated octahedral V-doped In
2
O
3
nanocrystals and the corresponding models with the same orientation. (b) Low-magnification TEM image.

div.div:
The concentration ratio of the precursors significantly affected the morphology of the In
2
O
3
nanocrystals and was a critical factor for the formation of truncated octahedral nanocrystals (
Figure
7
). When the ratio of V(acac)
3
to In(acac)
3
was low (≤0.5), the nanoparticles had a broad size distribution, with some nanoparticles as large as tens of nanometers. Conversely, a high ratio of the precursors (≥2) led to the formation of nanoparticles whose shape was not well-defined and irregular. Monodisperse nanoparticles were formed only with the appropriate ratio of the precursors (∼1). This result indicates that the presence of V ions with a proper concentration is critical to the formation of monodisperse and highly symmetric doped In
2
O
3
nanocrystals. The atomic percentage of V ions incorporated into the truncated octahedral nanocrystals was estimated to be ∼8.5% via EDS (prior to any further treatment, such as ligand exchange). Also, we notify that undoped In
2
O
3
nanoparticles with a narrow size distribution can be prepared in the absence of V(acac)
3
under different reaction conditions such as elevated reaction temperature (320 °C) or elongated reaction time (10 h). However, the undoped In
2
O
3
nanoparticles have less regular shapes compared to the well-defined V-doped In
2
O
3
nanoparticles and are occasionally fused together (
Figure S5
).

div.p:
Figure 7. TEM images of V-doped In
2
O
3
nanocrystals synthesized with different precursor concentration ratios: In/V = (a) 0.2:0, (b) 0.2:0.1, (c) 0.2:0.2, and (d) 0.2:0.4.

div.div:
XPS and Raman spectroscopy suggested that the vanadium(III) ions were incorporated into the In
2
O
3
host lattice. The XPS survey spectrum confirmed the presence of all the elements in the V-doped In
2
O
3
nanocrystals, including In, V (2p
3/2
, 2p
1/2
), and O (O 1s) (
Figure
8
a). Raman spectroscopy indicated that the nanoparticles were indeed crystalline In
2
O
3
because the peaks at 132, 306, 364, 495, and 630 cm
-1
all correspond to the vibrational modes of the cubic phase In
2
O
3
(
Figure
8
b).
(49,50)
The X-ray photoelectron spectra of the as-synthesized nanocrystals capped with oleates exhibited three O peaks at 529.78, 531.25, and 532.51 eV, corresponding to lattice oxygens (
O
L
), oxygens adjacent to vacancies (
O
V
), and chemisorbed oxygens (
O
C
), respectively (
Figure
8
c). Additionally, two V peaks were detected at 515.60 and 517.14 eV, corresponding to V
3+
and V
5+
ions, respectively (
Figure
8
d). Furthermore, XPS revealed a partial or complete removal of chemisorbed O and V ions upon ligand exchange with TOPO. TOPOs or TOPO derivatives are known to strongly bind to the surface of oxide nanocrystals and eliminate loosely bound surface chemical species.
(51−53)
The result suggests that pentavalent V ions were surface-adsorbed species and trivalent V ions were incorporated into the lattice of the nanocrystals. The amount of the V
3+
ions in the TOPO-treated nanocrystals was estimated to be ∼5.3% according to the XPS results, which is consistent with the EDS result (∼4.8%). TEM images of the TOPO-treated V-doped In
2
O
3
nanocrystals are presented in
Figure S6
.

div.p:
Figure 8. (a) XPS survey scan and (b) Raman spectrum for V-doped In
2
O
3
nanocrystals. XPS narrow scans of O 1s and V 2p for the product (c, d) before and (e, f) after TOPO treatment.

div.div:
Furthermore, we investigated the electrocatalytic performance of the TOPO-treated V-doped In
2
O
3
nanocrystals for the electrochemical reduction of CO
2
. Previously reported In-based electrocatalysts such as In metals and indium oxides typically reduce CO
2
to formic acid (HCOOH) and/or carbon monoxide (CO).
(37,38,54)
Notably, the V-doped In
2
O
3
nanocrystals produced methanol (CH
3
OH) in addition to HCOOH and CO.
Figure
9
a,b shows the potential (vs RHE) dependence of Faradic efficiencies (FEs) for the products. Over the whole range of applied potentials, CH
3
OH, HCOOH, and CO were generated as a result of CO
2
reduction. In general, the selectivities of CH
3
OH and CO increased as the potential decreased, while the selectivity of HCOOH was maximized at −1.17 V (vs RHE). The highest FE of CH
3
OH production was 15.8% at −0.83 V (vs RHE). H
2
was produced as a byproduct due to water electrolysis, for which the minimum FE was −1.17 V (vs RHE). The overall current density increased as the magnitude of the potential increased. On the other hand, the polydisperse nanoparticles obtained without OA etching step exhibit a lower Faradic efficiency for CH
3
OH production and total current density compared to those of monodisperse nanocrystals (
Figure S7
). The calibration curve and the
1
H NMR peak of CH
3
OH are presented in
Figure S8
.

div.p:
Figure 9. (a) Potential-dependent FEs of CO
2
RR products and overall current densities of the CO
2
RR electrocatalyzed by TOPO-treated V-doped In
2
O
3
nanocrystals. (b) FEs of the products measured at various applied potentials.

div.div:
The results indicate that the dopant had a significant effect on the reaction pathways. The schematic in
Figure
10
shows a typically suggested mechanism for CH
3
OH production using various electrocatalysts.
(55−61)
While HCOOH and CO productions require only two electron transfers, CH
3
OH production needs six electron transfers. For example, HCOOH is produced via a proton-coupled electron transfer (PCET) to the intermediates of *OCHO and/or *COOH, which are formed via a PCET or consecutive transfer of an electron and a proton to CO
2
. CO is produced from the *CO intermediate, which is formed by the PCET to the *COOH.
(55,56,62)
For the reaction to move forward along the pathway toward CH
3
OH production, the *CO intermediate should be sufficiently stabilized so that the next PCET step can occur. Provided that *CO is loosely bound, it is released as a gaseous carbon monoxide (CO
(g)
) product, which terminates the reaction pathway.
(58,63)
Apparently, the introduction of the V
3+
dopant to the In
2
O
3
nanocrystals strengthened the binding of the *CO intermediate and the nanocrystals. The enhancement of the binding energy could have been due to the π-backdonation of electrons from the highest occupied
d
orbital of the dopant ions to the lowest unoccupied π* antibonding orbital of CO, as is typically observed between transition-metal ions and CO molecules.
(39,40)
The results indicate that transition-metal doping has a significant effect on the stabilization of intermediates, moving the reduction further and causing the production of more reduced species.
(64,65)

div.p:
Figure 10. Possible reaction pathway for methanol production from the electrochemical reduction of CO
2
.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
We produced highly symmetrical doped oxide nanocrystals via a digestive-ripening process. First, injection of the digesting agent OA led to the complete etching of nonuniform and noncrystalline nanoparticles. Second, a nucleation burst was observed, followed by the growth of nanocrystals. Finally, during the digestive-ripening process, the size of the nanocrystals was focused from 11.5 ± 3.26 nm (28.3%) to 8.62 ± 0.89 nm (10.3%). The V dopant ions significantly affected the formation of the truncated octahedral shape and the monodispersity of the nanocrystals. Ligand-exchange and XPS analyses confirmed that the V
3+
ions were successfully incorporated into the In
2
O
3
lattice. Furthermore, we observed that the dopant clearly shifted the reaction pathway of CO
2
RR to produce CH
3
OH (FE = 15.8% at −0.83 V vs RHE), which was not observed for the previously reported In-based materials (
Table S1
). We suggest that π-backdonation from the transition-metal ions to the *CO intermediate stabilized the intermediate so that the reaction progressed, leading to CH
3
OH production. We believe that our results contribute to the digestive-ripening synthesis of oxide nanocrystals, to achieving a high product selectivity, and to the production of even further reduced products via the CO
2
RR.

Dimensionality and size are two factors that govern the properties of semiconductor nanostructures. In nanocrystals, dimensionality is manifested by the control of shape, which presents a key challenge for synthesis. So far, the growth of rod-shaped nanocrystals using a surfactant-controlled growth mode, has been limited to semiconductors with wurtzite crystal structures, such as CdSe. The authors report on a general method for the growth of sol. nanorods applied to semiconductors with the zinc-blende cubic lattice structure. InAs quantum rods with controlled lengths and diams. were synthesized using the soln.-liq.-solid mechanism with gold nanocrystals as catalysts. This provides an unexpected link between two successful strategies for growing high-quality nanomaterials, the vapor-liq.-solid approach for growing nanowires, and the colloidal approach for synthesizing sol. nanocrystals. The rods exhibit both length- and shape-dependent optical properties, manifested in a red-shift of the bandgap with increased length, and in the observation of polarized emission covering the near-IR spectral range relevant for telecommunications devices.

A review. A comprehensive overview of the process of digestive ripening that is known to convert polydisperse nanocrystals to monodisperse ones is presented. Apart from highlighting the role of org. mols. (ligands) in achieving size control, the roles of other parameters such as the nanocrystal-ligand binding strength and the temp. at which the reaction is carried out in accomplishing size control are also delineated. The generality of the procedure is illustrated by providing examples of how it is used to prep. monodisperse nanocrystals of different metals, alloy systems, and ultrasmall nanocrystals and also to narrow the size distribution in complex binary and ternary nanocrystal systems. Finally, the current status as far as the theor. understanding of how size control is being achieved by digestive ripening is laid out, emphasizing at the same time the necessity to undertake more systematic studies to completely realize the full potential of this practically very useful procedure.

A review with 196 refs. Soln. phase syntheses and size-selective sepn. methods to prep. semiconductor and metal nanocrystals, tunable in size from ∼1 to 20 nm and monodisperse to ≤5%, are presented. Prepn. of monodisperse samples enables systematic characterization of the structural, electronic, and optical properties of materials as they evolve from mol. to bulk in the nanometer size range. Sample uniformity makes it possible to manipulate nanocrystals into close-packed, glassy, and ordered nanocrystal assemblies (superlattices, colloidal crystals, supercrystals). Rigorous structural characterization is crit. to understanding the electronic and optical properties of both nanocrystals and their assemblies. At inter-particle sepns. 5-100 Å, dipole-dipole interactions lead to energy transfer between neighboring nanocrystals, and electronic tunneling between proximal nanocrystals gives rise to dark and photocond. At sepns. <5 Å, exchange interactions cause otherwise insulating assemblies to become semiconducting, metallic, or superconducting depending on nanocrystal compn. Tailoring the size and compn. of the nanocrystals and the length and electronic structure of the matrix may tune the properties of nanocrystal solid-state materials.

Single-phase approaches are introduced for the synthesis of nearly monodisperse Au and other noble metal nanocrystals. The new approaches possess all the advantages of the popular Brust method. With weak ligands or surfactants for the metal ions, the control of the size and size distribution of the nanocrystals in synthesis in the size range between 1 and 15 nm was achieved via maintaining balanced nucleation and growth by tuning the activities of the metal precursors and reducing reagents. Because only weak ligands are employed in the new synthetic schemes, surface modification and functionalization of the resulting nanocrystals can be readily carried out.

A review. Much progress has been made over the past ten years on the synthesis of monodisperse spherical nanocrystals. Mechanistic studies have shown that monodisperse nanocrystals are produced when the burst of nucleation that enables sepn. of the nucleation and growth processes is comined with the subsequent diffusion-controlled growth process through which the crystal size is detd. Several chem. methods have been used to synthesize uniform nanocrystals of metals, metal oxides, and metal chalcogenides. Monodisperse nanocrystals of CdSe, Co, and other materials have been generated in surfactant soln. by nucleation induced at high temp., and subsequent aging and size selection. Monodisperse nanocrystals of many metals and metal oxides, including magnetic ferrites, have been synthesized directly by thermal decompn. of metal-surfactant complexes prepd. from the metal precursors and surfactants. Nonhydrolytic sol-gel reactions have been used to synthesize various transition-metal-oxide nanocrystals. Monodisperse gold nanocrystals have been obtained from polydisperse samples by digestive-ripening processes. Uniform-sized nanocrystals of gold, silver, platinum, and palladium have been synthesized by polyol processes in which metal salts are reduced by alcs. in the presence of appropriate surfactants.

This paper provides direct evidence to support the role of a capping agent in controlling the evolution of Ag seeds into nanocrystals with different shapes. Starting with single-crystal seeds (spherical or cubic in shape), we could selectively obtain Ag octahedrons enclosed by {111} facets and nanocubes/nanobars enclosed by {100} facets by adding sodium citrate (Na3CA) and poly(vinyl pyrrolidone) (PVP), resp., as a capping agent while all other parameters were kept the same. This research not only offers new insights into the role played by a capping agent in shape-controlled synthesis but also provides, for the first time, Ag octahedrons as small as 40 nm in edge length for optical and spectroscopic studies.

A review; metal nanoparticles are key materials in heterogeneous catalysis due to their high catalytic activity and selectivity to the desired product. Accordingly, they are playing a pivotal role in most heterogeneous catalytic reactions that are steeply growing with the development of a colloidal synthetic protocol that enables fine control of size, shape, morphol. and compn. of metal nanoparticles at an at. level. These colloidal metal nanoparticles can be dispersed on a rigid support such as mesoporous silica, metal oxide and zeolite, which utilizes metal nanoparticles as model heterogeneous catalysts in industrially important processes involving hydrogenation/dehydrogenation, isomerization and cracking. In this review article, we highlight the recent progress on general colloidal synthetic routes with technol. advances in characterization tools that enable the at.-scale observation of metal nanoparticles. Structure-dependent contributions on the control of product selectivity and turnover rate are also discussed by combining advanced ex situ and in situ surface characterization tools that can monitor the structural change of metal nanocatalysts as well as the evolution of reaction intermediates under the reaction conditions.

This work has mainly investigated the influence of the solvent on the nanoparticles distribution in digestive ripening. The experiments suggested that the solvents played a key role in digestive ripening of Au nanoparticles (Au NPs). For the benzol solvents, the resulting size distribution of Au NPs was inversely related to the solvent polarity. It may be interpreted by the low Gibbs free energy of nanoparticles in the high polarity medium, which was supposedly in favor of reducing the nanoparticles distribution. Through digestive ripening in the highly polar benzol solvent of p-chlorotoluene, monodisperse Au NPs with relative standard deviation (RSD) of 4.8% were achieved. This indicated that digestive ripening was an effective and practical way to prepare high-quality nanoparticles, which holds great promise for the nanoscience and nanotechnology. Here we report the synthesis of monodispersed indium nanoparticles by evapn./condensation of indium shot using the solvated metal atom dispersion (SMAD) technique, followed by digestive ripening in low b.p. (BP 38 °C) methylene chloride and in a high b.p. (BP 110 °C) toluene solvent. The as-prepd. SMAD indium nanoparticles are polydispersed with particle size ranging from 25 to 50 nm, but upon digestive ripening (heating of colloidal material at the b.p. of solvent in presence of excess surface active ligands) in methylene chloride, a remarkable redn. of particle size was achieved. In higher boiling solvent (toluene), where the indium nanoparticles at reflux temp. are probably melted, it does not allow the best result, and less monodispersity is achieved. We employed different surface active ligands (amine, phosphine, and mixed ligands) to passivate these indium nanoparticles. The temporal evolution of the surface plasmon of indium nanoparticles was monitored by in situ UV-vis spectroscopy, and particles were characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and X-ray diffraction (XRD). The merits of this synthesis procedure are the use of bulk indium as starting material, tuning the particle size in low b.p. solvent, particle size adjustment with the choice of ligand, and a possible scale up.

Razgoniaeva, Natalia; Yang, Mingrui; Garrett, Paul; Kholmicheva, Natalia; Moroz, Pavel; Eckard, Holly; Royo Romero, Luis; Porotnikov, Dmitry; Khon, Dmitriy; Zamkov, Mikhail

Digestive ripening (DR) represents a powerful strategy for improving the size homogeneity of colloidal nanostructures. It relies on the ligand-mediated dissoln. of larger nanoparticles in favor of smaller ones and is often considered to be the opposite of Ostwald ripening. Despite its successful application to size-focusing of metal colloids, digestive ripening of semiconductor nanocrystals has received little attention to date. Here, we explore this synthetic niche and demonstrate that ligand-induced ripening of semiconductor nanocrystals exhibits an unusual reaction path. The unique aspect of the DR process in semiconductors lies in the thermally activated particle coalescence, which leads to a significant increase in the nanocrystal size for temps. above the threshold value (Tth = 200-220 °C). Below this temp., nanoparticle sizes focus to an ensemble av. diam. just like in the case of metal colloids. The existence of the thermal threshold for coalescence offers an expedient strategy for controlling both the particle size and the size dispersion. Such advanced shape control was demonstrated using colloids of CdS, CdSe, CsPbBr3, and CuZnSnS4, where monodisperse samples were obtained across broad diam. ranges. We expect the demonstrated approach to be extended to other semiconductors as a simple strategy for tuning the nanoparticle morphol.

Digestive ripening of bimetallic magnetic nanocrystals from uniform microsheets to spherical nanocrystals was obsd. in FeCoS2 nanocrystals leading to the formation of monodisperse nanocrystals. Earlier examples of digestive ripening are assocd. with the transformation of polydisperse particles to monodisperse particles deriving energetic stabilization from the monodispersity. However, it is interesting to note that in the current case, not only did we observe a transformation from uniform sheets to spherical particles but we also obsd. it in the absence of thiol, the most commonly used digestive ripening agent. We have then studied the effect of ligands such as oleic acid and oleylamine responsible for this ripening process. Long chain acids were found to be majorly responsible for digestive ripening while the amines assist in the formation of microsheets. A plausible mechanism has then been proposed.

A simple alloying procedure is described in which noble metal alloy nanoparticles are produced in gram quantities via digestive ripening. This process involves mixing of sep. prepd. colloids of Au and Ag or Cu particles and then heating in the presence of an alkanethiol (dodecane thiol) under reflux. The result after 1 h is alloy nanoparticles. The particles 5.6 ± 0.5 nm diam. for Au-Ag and 4.8 ± 1.0 nm diam. for Cu-Au undergo facile self-assembly to form 3-dimensional superlattice ordering. During this digestive ripening process, the org. ligands display an extraordinary chem. in which atom transfer between atomically pure copper, silver, and gold nanoparticles yields monodisperse alloy nanoparticles.

Co-digestive ripening is a versatile strategy for the prepn. of binary metal nanoparticles such as core-shell, composites, and alloys. The mechanism of co-digestive ripening is hypothesized to involve inter-atom transfer facilitated by capping agents. In this work, co-digestive ripening of a metal (Au) and a semiconductor (CdS) system has been presented. This process involves co-refluxing of a phys. mixt. of Au and CdS colloids in presence of hexadecyl amine (HDA) in mesitylene solvent. Individual colloids of Au and CdS were prepd. by solvated metal atom dispersion (SMAD) method. The growth control of nanoparticles using HDA resulted in the formation of monodisperse particles via a room temp. digestive ripening process. Au/CdS nanocomposite obtained via co-digestive ripening strategy was characterized by a matrix-like structure made up of CdS nanoparticles in which Au nanoparticles were embedded. CdS nanoparticles were found to establish an intimate surface contact with Au nanoparticles and the matrix of CdS surrounding Au was developed via aggregation during co-refluxing. Formation of the Au/CdS nanocomposite is proposed to involve a ligand replacement process wherein HDA mols. capping the Au surface are displaced by CdS owing to strong Au-CdS interaction. The Au/CdS composite thus obtained showed superior photocatalytic activity compared to pure CdS nanoparticles for dye degrdn. reaction.

This paper reports the synthesis and self-assembly of monodisperse icosahedral Ag, Au, and Pd nanoparticles with tunable sizes. Ag nanoparticles were 1st prepd. by a modified polyol method. The as-synthesized Ag nanoparticles were all icosahedral multiply twinned particles (MTPs) with notable size variations. The variability was reduced to <5% after a digestive ripening post treatment. The nearly monodisperse Ag nanoparticles were then used in replacement reactions with Au and Pd precursors to produce monodisperse icosahedral Au and Pd nanoparticles. The size of the monodisperse icosahedral Ag, Au, and Pd nanoparticles could also be increased thereafter by seed-mediated growth. The closely matched geometrical attributes of these icosahedral nanoparticles allowed them to easily self-assemble into 3-dimensional superlattices either in the soln. phase or on a solid substrate.

The authors describe a synthetic procedure for prepn. of large quantities of monodisperse thiol-stabilized Au colloids in toluene soln. The method is based on the solvated metal atom dispersion technique (SMAD), which is very suitable for prepn. of large amts. of metal colloidal solns., and of metal sulfide, metal oxide, and other types of dispersed compds. in different solvents. A combination of 2 different solvents like acetone and toluene is used for the prepn. of the Au colloids. The necessity of initially carrying out the SMAD reaction in acetone comes from its high degree of solvation of Au particles. Acetone acts as a preliminary stabilizing agent. After its removal from the system, the particles are stabilized by dodecanethiol mols., which enable their very good dispersion in toluene soln. A digestive ripening procedure is carried out with the Au-toluene colloid, and for this purpose pure toluene as solvent is necessary. This has a dramatic effect on the narrowing of particle size distribution and almost monodisperse colloids are obtained (some discussion of the probable mechanism of this remarkable digestive ripening step is given). These colloidal solns. have a great tendency to organize in 2- and 3-dimensional structures (nanocrystal superlattices, NCSs). Probably this procedure provides a real opportunity to synthesize large amts. of Au nanocrystals as well as NCSs.

Complex multivalent/mixed valent oxides involving two or more cations e.g. ABO3, AB2O4 and A2B2O7 exhibit the most fascinating range of phys. and chem. properties amongst the family of materials systems. There is growing interest in nanoscale forms of such oxides which emanates from the novel changes in their properties with size. To obtain nanomaterials with a high degree of crystallinity it is desirable to first make cryst. oxide powders by high temp. processing and then mill them down to nanometer size. In this paper we show that simple citric acid treatment of BiFeO3 and Bi2O3 powders leads to the desired micron-scale to nanoscale transformation, yielding nearly monodispersed nanoparticles. Importantly, these are highly dispersible and stable in water. By performing similar expts. on Fe3O4 and Fe2O3 we have elucidated the possible mechanism, which hinges on valence-controlled dissoln. and ripening phenomena.

The development of generic methods to synthesize monodisperse nanomaterials is one of the most crit. issues in the current research field of nanomaterial synthesis. In this work, we demonstrate for the first time that a digestive ripening process can produce monodisperse sub-10 nm lanthanide oxide nanodisks. Moreover, we show that nanodisks of nine different lanthanide oxides can be synthesized under the same reaction conditions. The successful synthesis is realized by employing a hot injection step to induce a single nucleation event and by introducing transition metal ions to delicately define the size and shape of the nanodisks in the digestive ripening process. Among the various nanodisks, Gd2O3, Dy2O3, and Ho2O3 nanodisks show promising magnetic properties as magnetic resonance imaging contrast agents. We expect that this novel synthetic route can be extended to various nanomaterials, including metallic and semiconducting nanocrystals.

The humidity dependence of the gas sensing characteristics of metal oxide semiconductors has been one of the greatest obstacles for gas sensor applications during the last five decades because ambient humidity dynamically changes with the environmental conditions. A new and novel strategy is reported to eliminate the humidity dependence of the gas sensing characteristics of oxide chemiresistors via dynamic self-refreshing of the sensing surface affected by water vapor chemisorption. The sensor resistance and gas response of pure In2O3 hollow spheres significantly change and deteriorate in humid atmospheres. In contrast, the humidity dependence becomes negligible when an optimal concn. of CeO2 nanoclusters is uniformly loaded onto In2O3 hollow spheres via layer-by-layer (LBL) assembly. Moreover, In2O3 sensors LBL-coated with CeO2 nanoclusters show fast response/recovery, low detection limit (500 ppb), and high selectivity to acetone even in highly humid conditions (relative humidity 80%). The mechanism underlying the dynamic refreshing of the In2O3 sensing surfaces regardless of humidity variation is investigated in relation to the role of CeO2 and the chem. interaction among CeO2, In2O3, and water vapor. This strategy can be widely used to design high performance gas sensors including disease diagnosis via breath anal. and pollutant monitoring.

Hydrogen doped indium oxide (In2O3:H) with excellent optoelectronic properties, deposited using at. layer deposition (ALD), has been made applicable as a window electrode material for silicon heterojunction (SHJ) solar cells. It is particularly challenging to integrate ALD In2O3:H into SHJ solar cells due to a low reactivity of the metalorg. precursor cyclopentadienyl indium (InCp) with the H-terminated surface of a-Si:H. This challenge has been overcome by a simple and effective plasma-based surface pretreatment developed in this work. A remote inductively coupled O2 or Ar plasma has been used to modify the surface of a-Si:H, thereby promoting the adsorption of InCp on the surface. The impact of the short plasma exposure on c-Si/a-Si:H interface passivation has also been studied. It has been found that the obsd. degrdn. of the interface is not due to ion bombardment, but rather due to UV emission from the plasma. Fortunately, these light-induced defects have been found to be metastable, and the interface passivation can thus easily be fully recovered by a short post-annealing. Using such a mild Ar plasma pretreatment, ALD In2O3:H has been successfully implemented in a SHJ solar cell. A short-circuit c.d. of 40.1 mA/cm2, detd. from external quantum efficiency, is demonstrated for a textured SHJ solar cell with an In2O3:H window electrode, compared to 38.5 mA/cm2 for a ref. cell that has the conventional Sn-doped indium oxide (In2O3:Sn, ITO) window electrode. The enhanced photocurrent stems from a reduced parasitic absorption of In2O3:H in the entire wavelength range of 400-1200 nm.

A review. During the last few years, transition metal oxides (TMO) such as molybdenum tri-oxide (MoO3), vanadium pent-oxide (V2O5) or tungsten tri-oxide (WO3) were extensively studied because of their exceptional electronic properties for charge injection and extn. in org. electronic devices. These unique properties led to the performance enhancement of several types of devices and to a variety of novel applications. TMOs were used to realize efficient and long-term stable p-type doping of wide band gap org. materials, charge-generation junctions for stacked org. light emitting diodes (OLED), sputtering buffer layers for semi-transparent devices, and org. photovoltaic (OPV) cells with improved charge extn., enhanced power conversion efficiency and substantially improved long term stability. Energetics in general play a key role in advancing device structure and performance in org. electronics; however, the literature provides a very inconsistent picture of the electronic structure of TMOs and the resulting interpretation of their role as functional constituents in org. electronics. With this review the authors intend to clarify some of the existing misconceptions. An overview of TMO-based device architectures ranging from transparent OLEDs to tandem OPV cells is also given. Various TMO film deposition methods are reviewed, addressing vacuum evapn. and recent approaches for soln.-based processing. The specific properties of the resulting materials and their role as functional layers in org. devices are discussed.

A shape controlled Cu2O/reduced graphene oxide/In2O3 (Cu2O/RGO/In2O3) hybrid with abundant oxygen vacancies was prepd. by a facile, surfactant-free method. The hybrid photocatalyst exhibits an increased photocatalytic activity in water oxidn. and degrdn. of environmental pollutants (methylene blue and Cr6+ solns.) compared with pure In2O3 and Cu2O materials. The presence of oxygen vacancies in Cu2O/RGO/In2O3 and the formation of heterojunction between In2O3 and Cu2O induce extra diffusive electronic states above the valence band (VB) edge and reduce the band gap of the hybrid consequently. Besides, the increased activity of Cu2O/RGO/In2O3 hybrid is also attributed to the alignment of band edge, a process that is assisted by different Fermi levels between In2O3 and Cu2O, as well as the charge transfer and distribution onto the graphene sheets, which causes the downshift of VB of In2O3 and the significant increase in its oxidn. potential. A built-in elec. field is generated on the interface of n-type In2O3 and p-type Cu2O, suppressing the recombination of photoinduced electron-hole pairs and allowing the photogenerated electrons and holes to participate in the redn. and oxidn. reactions for oxidizing water mols. and pollutants more efficiently.

Review. Synthetic control over inorg. nanocrystals has made dramatic strides so that a great no. of binary and a few ternary or more complex compds. can now be prepd. with good control over size and phys. properties. Recently, chemists have tackled the long-standing challenge of introducing dopant atoms into nanocrystals, and strategies that apply across diverse compns. are beginning to emerge. In this review, we 1st briefly summarize the array of characterization methods used to assess doping efficacy for ref. throughout the discussion. We then enumerate chem. strategies for doping with illustrative examples from the literature. A key concept is that the reactions leading to growth of the host crystal and to deposition of dopant ions must be balanced to succeed in incorporating dopants during crystal growth. This challenge has been met through various chem. strategies, and new methods, such as postsynthetic diffusion of dopant ions, continue to be developed. The opportunity to deliver new functionality by doping nanocrystals is great, particularly as characterization methods and synthetic control over introduction of multiple dopants advance.

From constraints from reported exptl. observations and d. functional theory simulations, the authors propose a mechanism for the redn. of CO2 to C2 products on Cu electrodes. To model the effects of an applied potential bias on the reactions, calcns. are carried out with a variable, fractional no. of electrons on the unit cell, which is optimized so that the Fermi level matches the actual chem. potential of electrons (i.e., the applied bias); an implicit electrolyte model allows for compensation of the surface charge so that neutrality is maintained in the overall simulation cell. The authors' mechanism explains the presence of the seven C2 species that were detected in the reaction, as well as other notable exptl. observations. Also, the authors' results shed light on the difference in activities toward C2 products between the (100) and (111) facets of Cu. The authors compare the authors' methodologies and findings with those in other recent mechanistic studies of the Cu-catalyzed CO2 redn. reaction.

A review. Digestive ripening has now been established as a very convenient route to obtain monodisperse nanoparticles from polydisperse ones by refluxing the latter in the presence of an excess ligand. Many ligands including long chain thiols, amines, or phosphines have been shown to be effective digestive ripening agents. It is hypothesized that the surface active groups of such digestive ripening agents bind and remove reactive surface atoms/clusters from big nanoparticles and redeposit them on smaller nanoparticles. In this way, large particles become smaller, while small particles become larger, and eventually, an equil. size is obtained that is specific to each of the digestive ripening agents used. Herein, the digestive ripening procedure is reviewed, discussed and its utility spanning the prepn. of monodispersed metal nanoparticles, alloy nanoparticles, superlattice structures and the most interesting nano-machining (wherein the monodisperse particles can be reverted back to the polydisperse system) is demonstrated.

Colloidal free-standing Cr3+-doped In2O3 nanocrystals were synthesized in oleylamine from indium (III) and chromium (III) acetylacetonate precursors. The nanocrystals were treated with trioctylphosphine oxide to remove surface-bound dopant ions and ensure internal doping. The lattice resolved TEM images reveal that nanocrystals are faceted and highly cryst., with no evidence of a secondary phase formation. The av. doping concn. estd. with energy dispersive x-ray spectroscopy at the single nanocrystal level agrees with the av. doping concn. from the analogous nanocrystal ensemble measurement. Ligand-field electronic absorption spectroscopy suggests that Cr3+ dopants are preferentially substituted for In3+ ions in their trigonally distorted octahedral (b) sites in In2O3 nanocrystals. Nanocryst. films, prepd. under mild conditions using colloidal Cr3+-doped In2O3 nanocrystals as building blocks, exhibit robust room temp. ferromagnetism. Structural and compositional analyses combined with the ligand-field spectroscopy indicate intrinsic ferromagnetism in this material. The ability to rationally synthesize and manipulate a new form of transition-metal-doped In2O3 nanocrystals opens up new opportunities for spintronics applications and may provide a framework for understanding the origin of ferromagnetism in transparent conducting oxides.

The authors report a method for the prepn. of colloidal ZnO-dild. magnetic semiconductor quantum dots (DMS-QDs) by alk.-activated hydrolysis and condensation of Zn acetate solns. in DMSO. Mechanistic studies reveal that Co2+ and Ni2+ dopants inhibit nucleation and growth of ZnO nanocrystals. In particular, dopants are quant. excluded from the crit. nuclei but are incorporated nearly isotropically during subsequent growth of the nanocrystals. The smaller nanocrystal diams. that result upon doping are explained by the Gibbs-Thompson relation between lattice strain and crystal soly. The authors describe methods for cleaning the nanocrystal surfaces of exposed dopants and for redispersion of the final DMS-QDs. Homogeneous substitutional doping is verified by high-resoln. low-temp. electronic absorption and MCD spectroscopies. A giant Zeeman effect is obsd. in the band gap transition of Co2+:ZnO DMS-QDs. MCD and Zeeman spectroscopies were used to quantify the magnitude of the p-d exchange interaction (N0β) that gives rise to this effect. N0β values of -2.3 ± 0.3 eV (-18,500 cm-1) for Co2+:ZnO and -4.5 ± 0.6 eV (-36,300 cm-1) for Ni2+:ZnO were detd. Ligand-to-metal charge-transfer transitions are obsd. in the MCD spectra of both Co2+:ZnO and Ni2+:ZnO DMS-QDs and are analyzed in the context of an optical electronegativity model. The importance of these charge-transfer states in detg. N0β is discussed. Ferromagnetism with TC > 350 K is obsd. in aggregated nanocrystals of Co2+:ZnO that unambiguously demonstrates the existence of intrinsic high-TC ferromagnetism in this class of DMSs.

Although TiO2, ZrO2, and HfO2 nanocrystals are often synthesized in tri-n-octylphosphine oxide (TOPO), it is unclear whether TOPO also serves as ligand. Using liq. and solid state 1H and 31P NMR spectroscopy and X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy, we show that the nanocrystal surface is capped by several derivs. of TOPO. In the 31P NMR spectrum, di-n-octylphosphinate (δ = 57 ppm) and P,P'-(di-n-octyl) pyrophosphonate (δ = 20 ppm) are found coordinated to the nanocrystal. In addn., hydrogen chloride assocs. with the metal oxide nanocrystal surface and protonates TOPO. The resulting hydroxyl-tri-n-octylphosphonium, [HO-PR3]+, is tightly assocd. with the nanocrystal surface (δ(31P) = 73 ppm) due to electrostatic interactions and hydrogen bonding. To simplify the complex surface compn., we exchange the original surface species for carboxylate or phosphonate ligands. The protonation of TOPO is an unexpected example of lyophilic ion pairing between an acidic metal oxide nanocrystal and a weakly basic ligand mol. that is formed in nonpolar soln. These results contrast with the classically envisaged L-type binding motif of TOPO to surface metal ions. The generality of this stabilization mode and its relevance to catalysis is discussed.

Both metallic indium and indium oxide electrocatalysts typically have high selectivity for producing formate via the electrochem. redn. of CO2 in aq. media. It has been suggested that under highly neg. potentials, i.e. potentials typically sufficient to reduce indium oxide to In0, the native oxide layer on metallic indium or indium oxide particles is not reduced to In0 when exposed to CO2-satd. electrolytes. This meta-stable oxide layer is crucial in the mechanism for producing formate via the two-electron, two-proton redn. of CO2; however it prevents the catalysis from occurring on In0. Herein, it is reported that electrochem. reducing In2O3 nanocatalysts in Ar-satd. electrolytes in situ, prior to CO2 exposure, will remove this metastable oxide layer and create an In0-In2O3 composite. This In0-In2O3 composite material changes the selectivity and is able to electrochem. reduce CO2 to CO with near 100% selectivity at relatively low overpotentials (c.a. -1.0 V vs. Ag/AgCl). The change in selectivity is attributed to the direct exposure of In0 to CO2 in soln. that typically does not exist due to the native oxide layer that forms on In metal. In addn., it was obsd. that the first electron-transfer step to form the surface adsorbed intermediates is highly reversible on the In0-In2O3 composite; however it is irreversible on an In foil electrode. The utilization is also reported of substrate generation-tip collection scanning electrochem. microscopy (SG-TC SECM) to measure the prodn. of CO as a function of applied potential. This technique allows for the collection of CO in situ during the voltammetry expt. as it is produced on the catalytic electrode, which results in accurate potential dependent measurements of CO prodn.

Electrochem. CO2 redn. (ECR) to value-added fuels and chems. provides a "clean" and efficient way to mitigate energy shortages and to lower the global carbon footprint. The unique structures of two-dimensional (2D) nanosheets and their tunable electronic properties make these nanostructured materials intriguing in catalysis. Various 2D nanosheets are showing promise for CO2 redn., depending on the preferred reaction product (HCOOH, CO, CH4, CH3OH, or CH3COOH). In this review, we focus on recent progress that has been achieved in using these 2D materials for ECR. We highlight procedures available for tuning catalytic activities of 2D materials and describe the fundamentals and future challenges of CO2 catalysis by 2D nanosheets.

Artificial photosynthesis can be used to store solar energy and reduce CO2 into fuels to potentially alleviate global warming and the energy crisis. Compared to the generation of gaseous products, it remains a great challenge to tune the product distribution of artificial photosynthesis to liq. fuels, such as CH3OH, which are suitable for storage and transport. Herein, the introduction is described of metallic Cu nanoparticles (NPs) on Cu2O films to change the product distribution from gaseous products on bare Cu2O to predominantly CH3OH by CO2 redn. in aq. solns. The specifically designed Cu/Cu2O interfaces balance the binding strengths of H* and CO* intermediates, which play crit. roles in CH3OH prodn. With a TiO2 model photoanode to construct a photoelectrochem. cell, a Cu/Cu2O dark cathode exhibited a Faradaic efficiency of up to 53.6 % for CH3OH prodn. This work demonstrates the feasibility and mechanism of interface engineering to enhance the CH3OH prodn. from CO2 redn. in aq. electrolytes.

The electrocatalytic CO2 redn. reaction (CO2RR) can dynamize the carbon cycle by lowering anthropogenic CO2 emissions and sustainably producing valuable fuels and chem. feedstocks. Methanol is arguably the most desirable C1 product of CO2RR, although it typically forms in negligible amts. In our search for efficient methanol-producing CO2RR catalysts, we have engineered Ag-Zn catalysts by pulse-depositing Zn dendrites onto Ag foams (PD-Zn/Ag foam). By themselves, Zn and Ag cannot effectively reduce CO2 to CH3OH, while their alloys produce CH3OH with Faradaic efficiencies of approx. 1 %. Interestingly, with nanostructuring PD-Zn/Ag foam reduces CO2 to CH3OH with Faradaic efficiency and c.d. values reaching as high as 10.5 % and -2.7 mA cm-2, resp. Control expts. and DFT calcns. pinpoint strained undercoordinated Zn atoms as the active sites for CO2RR to CH3OH in a reaction pathway mediated by adsorbed CO and formaldehyde. Surprisingly, the stability of the *CHO intermediate does not influence the activity.

Exptl. results have shown that CO2 electroredn. is sensitive to the surface morphol. of Cu electrodes. We used d. functional theory (DFT) to evaluate the thermodn. and kinetics of CO2 redn. pathways on Cu(100) and Cu(111) with the aim of understanding the exptl. reported differences in CO2 redn. products. Results suggest that the hydrogenation of CO* to hydroxymethylidyne (COH*) or formyl (CHO*) is a key selective step. Cu(111) favors COH* formation, through which methane and ethylene are produced via a common CH2 species under high overpotential (<-0.8 V vs RHE). On Cu(100), formation of CHO* is preferred and ethylene formation goes through C-C coupling of two CHO* species followed by a series of redn. steps of the C2 intermediates, under relatively lower overpotential (-0.4 to -0.6 V vs RHE). Further redn. of these C2 intermediates, however, require larger potentials (∼-1.0 V vs RHE) and conflicts with the exptl. obsd. low potential pathway to C2 products on Cu(100). Calcns. show that the presence of (111) step sites on the flat (100) terrace can reduce the overpotential for C2 prodn. on the Cu electrode, which may be present on Cu(100) due to reconstruction. On Cu(100), a change in CO* coverage from low to high with increasing neg. applied potential can trigger a switch from ethylene/ethanol to methane/ethylene as the redn. products by affecting the relative stability of CHO* and COH*.

CO2 electroredn. offers the possibility of producing hydrocarbon fuels using energy from renewable sources. Herein, the authors use d. functional theory to analyze the feasibility of CO2 electroredn. on a Fe(100) surface. Exptl., Fe is nonselective for hydrocarbon formation. A simplistic anal. of low-coverage reaction intermediate energies for the paths to produce CH4 and MeOH from CO2 suggests Fe(100) could be more active than Cu(111), currently the only metallic catalyst to show selectivity towards hydrocarbon formation. Impediments to CO2 electroredn. on Fe(100) including O*/OH* (* denotes surface bound species) blockage of active surface sites; competitive adsorption effects of H*, CO* and C*; and Fe carbide formation are considered. The authors' results indicate that under CO2 electroredn. conditions, Fe(100) is predicted to be covered in C* or CO* species, blocking any C-H bond formation. Further, bulk Fe is predicted to be unstable relative to FeCx formation at potentials relevant to CO2 electroredn. conditions.

The effect of the doped transition metal M (M = Ni, Pd and Pt) on CO2 redn. pathways and the origin of the electrocatalytic activity are investigated systematically by focusing on the CH4 and CH3OH formation pathways based on DFT calcns. assocd. with the computational hydrogen electrode model. Our studies show that the doping of Ni, Pd and Pt can promote CO2 redn. into hydrocarbons and influence the selectivity of redn. pathways, in which the doping of Pt may be able to lead to the strongest catalytic activity. The adsorption behavior between reaction intermediates and surfaces is crucial and the interactions of intermediates with the catalysts should be moderate in order to efficiently catalyze CO2 redn. into CH4 and CH3OH, and avoid OH surface poisoning. The enhanced electrocatalytic activity of transition metal-doped Cu(111) surfaces may be owing to decreased overpotential and moderate electronic interactions between Cu and the doped transition metals. The doped Ni, Pd and Pt atoms can considerably decrease the overpotential and remove surface OH poisoning, in which the doped Pt can simultaneously reduce overpotential for CO formation and further redn., and most easily remove OH, thus suggesting the best electrocatalytic activity. The moderate electron interaction between Cu and Pt and moderate upshift of the d-band center of Pt also explain why the Pt-doped Cu(111) surface has the best electrocatalytic activity for CO2 redn. Two possible descriptors can be proposed in order to scale the electrocatalytic activity of Cu-based electrocatalysts for CO2 redn., in which an ideal Cu-based electrocatalyst should be able to reduce barriers for CO formation and further redn., and should have moderate electron interactions between Cu and the doped transition metals, and a moderate upshift of d-band center of the doped transition metals. In these ways, CO2 redn. pathways can be facilitated and the yield of hydrocarbons CH4 and CH3OH can be enhanced.

A review. The electrochem. redn. of CO2 has gained significant interest recently as it has the potential to trigger a sustainable solar-fuel-based economy. In this Perspective, we highlight several heterogeneous and mol. electrocatalysts for the redn. of CO2 and discuss the reaction pathways through which they form various products. Among those, copper is a unique catalyst as it yields hydrocarbon products, mostly methane, ethylene, and ethanol, with acceptable efficiencies. As a result, substantial effort has been invested to det. the special catalytic properties of copper and to elucidate the mechanism through which hydrocarbons are formed. These mechanistic insights, together with mechanistic insights of CO2 redn. on other metals and mol. complexes, can provide crucial guidelines for the design of future catalyst materials able to efficiently and selectively reduce CO2 to useful products.

A review is given. Transformation of CO2 into various chems. including MeOH is a top priority field of study owing to the assocn. of CO2 with global warming. There is a need for renewable and sustainable energy sources and replacement of fossil fuel with a fuel with comparable energy d. Electrochem. redn. is a unique approach to convert CO2 to MeOH using alternative energy sources where electrocatalyst plays a crucial role. A lot of effort is made to understand and increase the efficiency of electrocatalysts. Unadulterated metals, metal oxide, composite materials, and metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) are used for the electrochem. redn. of CO2 to MeOH. However, MOFs engrossed the enormous consideration due to simplicity, higher surface area, and unique structural features. In recent years, MOFs and their derivs. find significant applications in the electrocatalysis of O and H evolution, O, H, and CO2 redn. The primary emphasis of this paper is the electroredn. of CO2 to MeOH by coalescing the vantages of non-MOFs, MOFs, and their composite materials. The challenges to achieve electrocatalyst with higher efficiency and better selectivity for the electroredn. of CO2 are analyzed. Several research directions are proposed for MOF electrocatalysts to enhance the catalytic efficiency in MeOH prodn. This paper substantiates the efforts to develop new MOFs with superior efficiency, chem. stability, and cond.

Linear scaling relations between reaction intermediates pose a fundamental limitation to the CO2 redn. activity of transition-metal catalysts. To design improved catalysts, the authors propose to break these scaling relations by binding key reaction intermediates to different sites. Using d. functional theory, the authors demonstrate this principle in the active edge sites in MoS2, MoSe2, and Ni-doped MoS2. These edges show the unique property of selectively binding COOH and CHO to bridging S or Se atoms and CO to the metal atom. DFT calcns. suggest a significant improvement in CO2 redn. activity over the transition metals. The authors' results point to the broader application of the active edge sites of transition-metal dichalcogenides in complex electrochem. processes.

This paper demonstrates the rapid and precise size selection of nanoparticle populations using the pressure tunable solvent properties of CO2-expanded liqs. Specifically, by pressurizing and expanding a single org. soln. with carbon dioxide gas, ligand-stabilized silver particles of desired mean size were size selectively pptd. at desired locations. Compared to current techniques, this CO2-expanded liq. approach provides for faster and more efficient particle size sepn., redn. in org. solvent usage, and pressure tunable size selection.

Dimensionality and size are two factors that govern the properties of semiconductor nanostructures. In nanocrystals, dimensionality is manifested by the control of shape, which presents a key challenge for synthesis. So far, the growth of rod-shaped nanocrystals using a surfactant-controlled growth mode, has been limited to semiconductors with wurtzite crystal structures, such as CdSe. The authors report on a general method for the growth of sol. nanorods applied to semiconductors with the zinc-blende cubic lattice structure. InAs quantum rods with controlled lengths and diams. were synthesized using the soln.-liq.-solid mechanism with gold nanocrystals as catalysts. This provides an unexpected link between two successful strategies for growing high-quality nanomaterials, the vapor-liq.-solid approach for growing nanowires, and the colloidal approach for synthesizing sol. nanocrystals. The rods exhibit both length- and shape-dependent optical properties, manifested in a red-shift of the bandgap with increased length, and in the observation of polarized emission covering the near-IR spectral range relevant for telecommunications devices.

A review. A comprehensive overview of the process of digestive ripening that is known to convert polydisperse nanocrystals to monodisperse ones is presented. Apart from highlighting the role of org. mols. (ligands) in achieving size control, the roles of other parameters such as the nanocrystal-ligand binding strength and the temp. at which the reaction is carried out in accomplishing size control are also delineated. The generality of the procedure is illustrated by providing examples of how it is used to prep. monodisperse nanocrystals of different metals, alloy systems, and ultrasmall nanocrystals and also to narrow the size distribution in complex binary and ternary nanocrystal systems. Finally, the current status as far as the theor. understanding of how size control is being achieved by digestive ripening is laid out, emphasizing at the same time the necessity to undertake more systematic studies to completely realize the full potential of this practically very useful procedure.

A review with 196 refs. Soln. phase syntheses and size-selective sepn. methods to prep. semiconductor and metal nanocrystals, tunable in size from ∼1 to 20 nm and monodisperse to ≤5%, are presented. Prepn. of monodisperse samples enables systematic characterization of the structural, electronic, and optical properties of materials as they evolve from mol. to bulk in the nanometer size range. Sample uniformity makes it possible to manipulate nanocrystals into close-packed, glassy, and ordered nanocrystal assemblies (superlattices, colloidal crystals, supercrystals). Rigorous structural characterization is crit. to understanding the electronic and optical properties of both nanocrystals and their assemblies. At inter-particle sepns. 5-100 Å, dipole-dipole interactions lead to energy transfer between neighboring nanocrystals, and electronic tunneling between proximal nanocrystals gives rise to dark and photocond. At sepns. <5 Å, exchange interactions cause otherwise insulating assemblies to become semiconducting, metallic, or superconducting depending on nanocrystal compn. Tailoring the size and compn. of the nanocrystals and the length and electronic structure of the matrix may tune the properties of nanocrystal solid-state materials.

Single-phase approaches are introduced for the synthesis of nearly monodisperse Au and other noble metal nanocrystals. The new approaches possess all the advantages of the popular Brust method. With weak ligands or surfactants for the metal ions, the control of the size and size distribution of the nanocrystals in synthesis in the size range between 1 and 15 nm was achieved via maintaining balanced nucleation and growth by tuning the activities of the metal precursors and reducing reagents. Because only weak ligands are employed in the new synthetic schemes, surface modification and functionalization of the resulting nanocrystals can be readily carried out.

A review. Much progress has been made over the past ten years on the synthesis of monodisperse spherical nanocrystals. Mechanistic studies have shown that monodisperse nanocrystals are produced when the burst of nucleation that enables sepn. of the nucleation and growth processes is comined with the subsequent diffusion-controlled growth process through which the crystal size is detd. Several chem. methods have been used to synthesize uniform nanocrystals of metals, metal oxides, and metal chalcogenides. Monodisperse nanocrystals of CdSe, Co, and other materials have been generated in surfactant soln. by nucleation induced at high temp., and subsequent aging and size selection. Monodisperse nanocrystals of many metals and metal oxides, including magnetic ferrites, have been synthesized directly by thermal decompn. of metal-surfactant complexes prepd. from the metal precursors and surfactants. Nonhydrolytic sol-gel reactions have been used to synthesize various transition-metal-oxide nanocrystals. Monodisperse gold nanocrystals have been obtained from polydisperse samples by digestive-ripening processes. Uniform-sized nanocrystals of gold, silver, platinum, and palladium have been synthesized by polyol processes in which metal salts are reduced by alcs. in the presence of appropriate surfactants.

This paper provides direct evidence to support the role of a capping agent in controlling the evolution of Ag seeds into nanocrystals with different shapes. Starting with single-crystal seeds (spherical or cubic in shape), we could selectively obtain Ag octahedrons enclosed by {111} facets and nanocubes/nanobars enclosed by {100} facets by adding sodium citrate (Na3CA) and poly(vinyl pyrrolidone) (PVP), resp., as a capping agent while all other parameters were kept the same. This research not only offers new insights into the role played by a capping agent in shape-controlled synthesis but also provides, for the first time, Ag octahedrons as small as 40 nm in edge length for optical and spectroscopic studies.
